quotes.topic_title: Early Facebook grind and startup reality
quotes.text: I didn't sleep for more than four hours at a time. I'd wake up every four hours and check the report and see if anyone was attacking the site. They don't tell you about that stuff in the movies.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of the operational paranoia and on-call reality that often defines early-stage startups but is rarely glamorized.

quotes.topic_title: Early Facebook grind and startup reality
quotes.text: I don't want to take away from the romanticism of it. It's just that most often, we hear those romantic stories from the successes. It's a healthy thing for people to want to throw themselves into something and take that risk, but it is not glamorous at the time.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A survivorship-bias reminder that helps practitioners calibrate expectations about risk, sacrifice, and what “startup life” actually feels like day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Early Facebook grind and startup reality
quotes.text: Now, newsfeed was an easier case than people suspect. Everyone was outraged at the same time as they immediately doubled their usage of the product.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product lesson: loud backlash can coexist with (or even signal) strong engagement, so measure behavior, not just sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
quotes.text: But the first thing I tell founders is like, "You should take my advice with a grain of salt. I have not actually been in your shoes."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical reminder to calibrate advice based on the advisor’s direct experience and context-match.

quotes.topic_title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
quotes.text: And by the nature of the rapid pace of change in the technology, and the nature of the engagement of those institutions, even academics, even academia broadly, kind of are out of touch. The tools that you got from those places weren't useful in our field.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of traditional institutions that explains why founders should seek more current, practitioner-driven learning sources.

quotes.topic_title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
quotes.text: So, I do think the mentorship that we give each other has been a critical and sustaining resource. There is, today, now, resources like your podcasts and your newsletter that are actually really designed to help people who are professionals in our industry in a way that is almost kind of missing for 15, 20 years, and I love to see that.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Frames peer mentorship and modern media as a scalable replacement for missing professional support structures.

quotes.topic_title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
quotes.text: No matter how far you dial back, the challenges are interesting and are worth talking about.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A scale-invariance mental model: many founder problems repeat across company stages, making shared experience broadly reusable.

quotes.topic_title: Advice to founders and value of mentorship
quotes.text: The advice I find I have to give more frequently than any other in my career, as a manager, a board member, an advisor and a friend, is for people to more directly leverage their leaders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a high-leverage, often underused tactic: proactively using leadership as a resource rather than working around them.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Boz is the chief technology officer of Meta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Boz’s current scope and authority, framing the credibility behind later leadership and product lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He joined what was then called Facebook in early 2006 as one of the first engineers, and during his 18-year tenure at Meta, he created some of the most impactful and important products in internet history, including the Facebook newsfeed, which was the first ever algorithmically ranked content feed of any social network, and is basically what people think of as Facebook today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a single product innovation (algorithmic ranking) can redefine an entire company and category.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our wide-ranging conversation, we touch on so many important lessons and stories, what it was really like in the early days of Facebook, why you should be asking your manager for help more often, why communication is the job.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights two actionable leadership principles—proactively seeking help and treating communication as core work, not overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And in 2017, he created the company's AR/VR organization, now called Reality Labs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific organizational move that illustrates how leaders formalize new bets by creating dedicated structures and ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance, alongside reporting and tracking risks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Highlights a continuous-monitoring approach to compliance that practitioners can apply to reduce point-in-time audit scramble.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Actionable efficiency lever: automate repetitive security questionnaire work to reclaim time for higher-impact security tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features, and Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Frames a growth methodology: pair faster experiment throughput with deeper analysis to learn more per unit time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, an accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Provides concrete, practitioner-relevant tactics for speeding up experimentation: better stats, self-serve analysis, and standardized reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Boz fun facts and prom story
quotes.text: I got to make sure that people understand, I was a national collegiate champion, in as a green belt, which that's like being the JV champion. Just so everyone's clear on what that is.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A useful reminder to calibrate credentials precisely and communicate the real level of achievement to avoid misleading impressions.

quotes.topic_title: Boz fun facts and prom story
quotes.text: And almost every 4-H event has a dance. People don't know that.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Highlights an overlooked pattern in a system (events consistently ending in dances), pointing to how hidden structures create repeated opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Boz fun facts and prom story
quotes.text: And so, as a consequence, the most important thing, if wanted to go to a lot of proms, I was a good dancer.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of skill-building compounding into social outcomes—develop one leveraged skill and it unlocks many doors.

quotes.topic_title: Boz fun facts and prom story
quotes.text: And it turns out, the high-level bit, at least in the 1990s, for girls selecting who they might want to go to prom with was, will he and can he dance?
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A memorable “selection criteria” mental model: identify the real decision rule in a market (or social setting) and optimize for it.

quotes.topic_title: Boz fun facts and prom story
quotes.text: Two my junior year and 12 my senior year. I once went to three in one weekend, a Friday, a Saturday, and a Sunday night.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Specific data points that illustrate how repeated access plus a differentiating skill can scale results dramatically.

quotes.topic_title: Leverage your manager more directly
quotes.text: But what so often we forget is, more often than not, your job is not to do it yourself. Your job is to get it done, is to have the thing done, done well, done right, done competently.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Reframes success from personal independence to outcomes, making asking for help a core part of doing the job well.

quotes.topic_title: Leverage your manager more directly
quotes.text: Or they come back, and it took a year. And I'm like, "Why did this take a year instead of six months?" And they're like, "Oh, man. I had all these things I had to deal with." Where, if they had emailed me, I could have bulldozed that stuff. I could have cleared the path. I could have said, " Oh, no, no, no. Don't worry about that. This is the thing." And then we'd have been done six months sooner, and they would've been less frustrated. And so, light touches.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Concrete example of how small, early check-ins with a manager can remove blockers and cut timelines dramatically.

quotes.topic_title: Leverage your manager more directly
quotes.text: And one of my things I always tell my managers, one of the most powerful things we do is refuse to rule.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leadership tactic: sometimes the best managerial support is explicitly not giving an answer, to build ownership and judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Leverage your manager more directly
quotes.text: That's like your manager. Nobody wants you to be more awesome than your manager does, because when you're amazing, your manager, his life gets easier, her life gets easier.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Mental model for overcoming fear of asking for help: your manager is structurally incentivized to help you succeed.

quotes.topic_title: Leverage your manager more directly
quotes.text: So, I just think that's the mentality we get into is like, "No, no, no. They're testing me." They're not. They are rooting for you. I promise you that.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that seeking guidance signals weakness, emphasizing that leaders generally want you to win.

quotes.topic_title: Practical tactics for asking for help
quotes.text: You can say, "Hey, I'm making progress on this. This is what I'm blocked on, this is the current program." And I'll even say, "Hey, if this all looks good to you, no response required. If there is something here that you want me to do better, different, that you think you could help with, let me know."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical template for asking for help that reduces perceived risk and makes it easy for a manager to engage.

quotes.topic_title: Practical tactics for asking for help
quotes.text: I love a typed, five-, 10-sentence email, "No response required. Here's where things are."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A lightweight written update creates a steady “heartbeat” without demanding attention, while keeping leaders informed.

quotes.topic_title: Practical tactics for asking for help
quotes.text: Even then, when you're blocked, you can make my life super easy. Like, "Hey, what I'd love for you to do, if you could send an email to this person, here's a draft with this thought, that would help."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Shows how to “make it cheap” for leaders to help by providing a ready-to-send draft and clear next action.

quotes.topic_title: Practical tactics for asking for help
quotes.text: So now, not only am I up to speed, I have a mental model, I'm engaged. Also, you've made it super cheap for me to help you.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: the best help-requests minimize the manager’s effort while maximizing clarity and context.

quotes.topic_title: Practical tactics for asking for help
quotes.text: It's a little spinning plates at my scale.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A vivid leadership metaphor that reframes exec work as many small touches to maintain momentum across many initiatives.

quotes.topic_title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
quotes.text: Yeah. This kind of comes back to, I think, the principle that really good, talented people, you want to leverage them fully. You really want to make sure that they are fully leveraged. And so, anytime they have the wrong information, or they don't have the information, you've now blocked one of the economically most valuable things that your company possesses, which is this person's time, attention, talent. Not only that, you've also made them more frustrated, and now they are more likely to leave.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A clear mental model for transparency as a way to maximize talent leverage and retention by preventing information bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
quotes.text: People talk about top-down or bottoms-up culture, and it's a bit of a myth, in my opinion. If you've ever met Mark Zuckerberg, it's not a bottoms-up thing. The ideas that we're pursuing are Mark Zuckerberg's ideas, first and foremost.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A contrarian take that challenges the common narrative about Meta being primarily bottoms-up, reframing how big-company idea generation actually works.

quotes.topic_title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
quotes.text: Now, it does come at a tremendous price. You have to get really good at managing information on the incoming.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical warning that radical transparency requires building personal and organizational capability to handle information overload.

quotes.topic_title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
quotes.text: You have to have a system for managing your information. You have to have a system for triaging the incoming, getting rid of a bunch of stuff that is on the wrong channel, or it doesn't matter to you, figuring out what's the... groups that you want to be a part of, but you consume only when you choose to and-
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: treat transparency as an input-triage problem and use deliberate consumption systems to find signal in noise.

quotes.topic_title: Meta transparency: benefits, costs, and leaks
quotes.text: Just feels like a violation of the team trust. Just feels like... I grew up with playing sports, right? I was football, soccer, track. And you just can't imagine one of your guys calling out the play to the other team. Can you imagine what you would do in that case? "You're off the team. I'm sorry, you can't be here."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that frames leaks as a team-trust breach, clarifying why transparency depends on strong norms and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
quotes.text: But make no mistake, like Mark or me or Chris Cox or Javi, they have very strong opinions about what we should be doing as a company, and your bottoms up-ness works within that framework.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Clarifies a practical model: teams can be bottom-up, but only within a top-down strategic framework set by leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
quotes.text: So I don't know, it's just not as black and white as people tend to paint it.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Challenges the simplistic “bottom-up vs top-down” narrative and encourages leaders to design hybrid decision systems.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
quotes.text: And can I tell you, the most important thing is just giving people clear guidelines so they know where they... Like, "Where do they have space and where do they have no space?"
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Actionable advice: autonomy works best when teams have explicit boundaries about what’s flexible vs fixed.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
quotes.text: For this part of the UI, it is going to... Like, I will draw it for you. It's going to be like this." And this other part. I'm like, "Cool, that's important, too. I don't have a clear vision of it. Why don't you do it?"
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Concrete example of “guardrails”: leaders should be prescriptive where they have conviction and delegate exploration where they don’t.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up vs top-down and clear guardrails
quotes.text: So there's just really clear guardrails of like, "Okay, where are we just on assignment? And where do we have more flexibility?"
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Provides a memorable framing for operating cadence: explicitly label work as “assignment” vs “flexible” to reduce confusion and speed execution.

quotes.topic_title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
quotes.text: Such a useless answer for founders, it depends on the weeds. There are some weeds that really matter and there's some weeds that really just don't, and I should say, that doesn't mean they don't matter at all. You have to do them, but they aren't the hinge upon which success or failure will happen.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for when leaders should go deep: focus on the details that are true “hinges” for success/failure.

quotes.topic_title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
quotes.text: For me, the judgment is like, "How do you, most important, determine what is what matters the most?" And so Mark, we joke inside of Meta, to this day, we call it the eye of Sauron. When Mark has determined that the thing that you're working on is the most important thing, there is no detail too small for him to notice.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model (“eye of Sauron”) for how executive attention intensifies on the highest-priority work.

quotes.topic_title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
quotes.text: He will be in a review, and in the same review. We'll be like, "Strategically, I think we're off course. And also, this one pixel is definitely wrong. You have to fix that." That's a big range.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A concrete example of effective “zooming” between strategy and tiny execution details in the same leadership moment.

quotes.topic_title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
quotes.text: I was really adamant, for example, that hand tracking and mixed reality make it into the headset. Let's just say that there weren't any supporters in the team.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: Shows a counterintuitive leadership move: forcing through a pivotal feature despite internal skepticism.

quotes.topic_title: When leaders go deep: pixels to strategy
quotes.text: You also suffer in the shadow of its absence. There's no perfect place to be.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A nuanced observation that both intense executive scrutiny and lack of executive attention create real costs for teams.

quotes.topic_title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
quotes.text: You're choosing your customers as much as your customers are choosing you, is one way I think about it sometimes, and one mistake that you do see sometimes startups make is they get an early cohort of users whose needs actually take them kind of orthogonal to a larger market. And so they become kind of held hostage by their earliest customers now.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for avoiding early-user lock-in that pulls a product away from the broader market.

quotes.topic_title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
quotes.text: Now News Feed was an easier case than people suspect, because everyone was outraged at the same time as they immediately doubled their usage of the product.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example of backlash paired with strong engagement signals—useful for interpreting launches beyond sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
quotes.text: And so we were like, Okay, wait, there's cognitive dissonance here between what the stated preferences and what the revealed preferences are in the economic sense.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical lens for product decisions: prioritize revealed behavior over what users say they want.

quotes.topic_title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
quotes.text: So another thing to know is like, "When did you screw something small up, and when did you do something big up?" When is the thing itself wrong, versus when were the details wrong? That is an art. That is a real art, and you don't always have user data to determine it like we did.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A decision framework for separating flawed execution from a flawed core idea—especially when data is ambiguous.

quotes.topic_title: News Feed launch backlash and conviction
quotes.text: And so a lot of that is, "Do you have a clear vision and intuition for what you expected to happen?" And then what happened instead and can you diagnose the delta there?
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: An actionable method for post-launch learning: compare expected vs actual outcomes and diagnose the gap.

quotes.topic_title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
quotes.text: What I have learned since then is to give myself a space to understand if I can get passionate about it.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A practical career heuristic: don’t prematurely reject a role—create a trial period to see if genuine interest emerges.

quotes.topic_title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
quotes.text: Now, there are parts of jobs that I've had before where I just never found the passion, and after six months I just have to move on.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A concrete timebox for evaluating fit—if it doesn’t click after sustained effort, it may be time to change roles.

quotes.topic_title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
quotes.text: I was kind of joking it was like, for those who are old enough to remember Karate Kid, I felt like I was painting a lot of fences, waxing a lot of cars, and at the end I knew karate.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for compounding learning: seemingly disconnected tasks/roles can build an integrated skillset over time.

quotes.topic_title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
quotes.text: And then when I finally turned the corner, really with the ads appointment, which I did for five years, I went vertical. I just like my career went vertical.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A specific example of how breadth early on can set up a later inflection point when you find a deep domain worth sticking with.

quotes.topic_title: Passion, identity, and exploring new domains
quotes.text: And so advice I most often give people, for me at least, the lesson that I take from this, is I just was willing to learn aggressively. I would move because I wasn't learning enough. I was bored, and so I wasn't learning enough new stuff.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: An actionable decision rule: optimize for learning rate (and move when it stalls) rather than staying put for linear progression.

quotes.topic_title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
quotes.text: I really almost changed jobs every six months for a long time.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A concrete early-career tactic: intentionally rotate roles frequently to maximize exposure and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
quotes.text: I was kind of joking it was like, for those who are old enough to remember Karate Kid, I felt like I was painting a lot of fences, waxing a lot of cars, and at the end I knew karate.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for how seemingly disconnected experiences compound into real capability over time.

quotes.topic_title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
quotes.text: And it probably at some point early in my career felt like I was moving more slowly relative to my peers.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: optimizing for learning/variety can look like slower progress before it pays off.

quotes.topic_title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
quotes.text: I would move because I wasn't learning enough. I was bored, and so I wasn't learning enough new stuff.
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for career moves: use learning rate (not comfort or title) as the primary signal.

quotes.topic_title: Career strategy: optimize for learning and variety
quotes.text: And so for me, it's like, "Jump into new things, give it six months. If it's not the thing, no problem. You just built a ton of new skills that's going to come in handy, I promise you that. Keep going."
quotes.speaker: Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth
quotes.context: An actionable playbook for experimentation: time-box new roles and treat each stint as skill compounding.
